review_title: I company worth staying If it doesn't get "Bluewashed" by IBM
pros: One of the benefits of working at Red Hat is the culture of openness and flexibility in regards to how I choose to work. This includes being able to select the operating system and tools that I prefer to use on a daily basis. Additionally, Red Hat provides amenities such as snacks and a gym and cafeteria on site, which adds to the convenience and overall work experience. RedHat occasionally throws party's and events at the workplace which is a nice benefit, but most of the time its just < 10% of what it used to be.
cons: As an employee of Red Hat, I have found that the culture here allows for a great deal of flexibility in terms of the tools and operating systems I use on a daily basis. However, I have noticed that bonus pay and raises can be somewhat stagnant. While Red Hat has historically been known for its strong workplace culture, the transition to remote work during the COVID-19 pandemic has made it more difficult to maintain the sense of connection that used to exist. Additionally, the acquisition by IBM has led to some concerns about the potential for cultural changes that could negatively impact the company. Overall, it feels as though the focus on the bottom line has increased, leading to a feeling of being a small cog in a large machine. RedHat has a difficult legal policy on terminating employees and can be difficult to navigate. I have witnessed repeated mistakes being made without adequate disciplinary action being taken. As a result, many top engineers have left the team due to these issues, which can be a burden on the rest of the team. It's important to hold team members accountable for their actions and to address any performance issues in a timely manner. (North America)

pros: Red Hat has an incredible work/life balance offering in that they drive the message that people should not be working out of their hourly working week (late nights and weekends). This is rare in the tech world and Red Hat also do a quarterly learning day to increase your skillset and have a quarterly day off for rest. I was on 15% and it just increased to 20% and is paid quarterly which is nice in your pay packet every few months, we have always hit bonus since I've been here. A pro is the open culture in that everyone has a 'heard voice' but this can also be a con.
cons:
There's no hierarchy and everyone has an opinion. To get basic tasks done, no one takes accountability or responsibility. There are no KPIs/OKRs rolled down from senior management so a majority of the team do not know what they are working towards. Many senior people have progressed into senior roles due to politics, not because of meritocracy (one of Red Hat's values). Given that the company is so 'transparent' (another RH value) it's ironic that everyone's calendars are blocked and private, rearrange or don't turn up to meetings and that so many people can hide behind the new WFH culture - especially as there's no KPIs to outline whether people are/n't achieving. It's a very frustrating culture that people of my seniority or a role higher feel they are too busy to take certain meetings or to communicate down to their teams. 

If you look at Red Hat competition you don't get this same culture and there is increased camaraderie within teams - reset and learning days don't compensate for authentic people. 

Onboarding is non existent compared to other companies and internal processes to try and get anything done e.g. it took me a week to ask for a copy of my work contract and six weeks to get licenses for any tools I need to do my job. The processes are absolutely over engineered and made so much more complex than required.

We were acquired by IBM a few years ago and I'm sure it's not going to be long until they realize how many lazy people there are hiding behind a trusted WFH culture. They'll also appreciate that a lot of the processes are inefficient and driven by long term legacy employees - not innovative people who have seen best practices in other businesses.

Disastrous changes have made Red Hat a top-down, full silo structure. Rapidly expanded workforce consisting of just whoever HR could scrape up. Paperwork, paperwork, and more paperwork is now the norm. Processes appear overnight, with a team of thirty new hires to manage and enforce them in ways that only serve to inhibit day-to-day work. Whether this is IBM's influence or simply the fate of all businesses, I cannot say.

As has been mentioned in other reviews, "culture" is fanatical a term that gets tossed around without any weight behind it. There is a definite long-standing issue with sexual harassment, with repeat offenders escaping repercussions for years, only to be later promoted.

Direct people-level management can be kind, but are in many way powerless. Mid level and upwards are self-aggrandizing and fall into buckets as either sociopaths or essentially useless cheerleaders with no in-between.

Career opportunities belong to white males in Westford that rub elbows with the rest of the boy's club. For that in-crowd, the company is just a playground.

job_title: Software Architect in Los Angeles, CA
pros:
Red Hat is a meritocracy. If you put in the hours, do good work, always work to improve your skillset and advocate for yourself, you will find success. I hired in as a Consultant with no tech degree (self taught Java). Through hard work and advocating for myself, I made it to Consulting Architect in 6 years. Others have done it much faster.

Even though the company has become more corporate as it has grown, there is still a Wild West sense to some of the divisions (I've worked in 3 different divisions over 10 years). With that chaos lies opportunity, but also unease if you desire more structure. Be cognizant of this when hiring into a division. If the division culture is too staid or not startup-y enough, transfers are usually allowed.

I very much enjoy working with other people at Red Hat. Even though we come from a relatively diverse set of backgrounds (by tech's standards), we all have common ground in the work we do and the culture of the company.

If you are passionate about something tangentially related to your work, you are encouraged to pursue that. Whether that be building a rack, writing bootstrapping code or working on open source projects, Red Hat rewards go-getters.
cons:
The acquisition by IBM hangs over the company. There is a sense that if RH slips in growth or profits once, the IBM overlords will assimilate our culture to be more like IBM to 'fix' us. While this may not be true, that potentiality is openly discussed.

Some of the software suites RH develops have lofty physical requirements. Many employees that have to deal wth that software in a daily capacity have had to resort to building their own home labs in order to run the software to learn and resolve client issues.

review_title: Talks a big game, does not deliver
pros: Until the IBM acquisition, the employee return on stock RSUs was pretty good.
cons:
Senior career opportunities at Red Hat are hidden well out of view. If you are an engineer or other individual, you can make it to principal through hard work and results. If you are a manager, the only career options open to you are entirely based on who you know and depend your narrow personal group — other units are insular and out of reach. 

The CEO talks a big game of ideals and Open Source openness. Quite simply interviewing folks for promotions, or even just posting the opening for internal applicants (instead of secretly deciding who of your friends gets promoted) are old practices that companies a lot less full of themselves have followed for decades. In Red Hat, senior openings  are an exercise in closed door decisions for the existing old boys club. 

Let's not get even started on diversity. This is the most white, male company I have worked at, and this is not a particularly diverse industry so the baseline would be so easy to beat.
